mnemonic: ZERO sounds almost identical - just Portuguese accent!
cultural_note: Zero is used in phone numbers temperature and sports scores
tip: Pronounce with Portuguese 'r' sound (slightly different from English)

mnemonic: UM sounds like 'OOM' - rhymes with room. ONE room!
grammar_notes: Also means 'a/an' (indefinite article) for masculine nouns
cultural_note: Um is nasal - let the sound resonate in your nose
tip: The nasal 'um' sound is key to sounding Portuguese!

mnemonic: DOIS - 'DOY' like 'boy' + 'SH' = two boys say shh!
cultural_note: In casual speech you might hear 'dos' without the 'i'

mnemonic: TRÊS sounds like 'TRAY' + 'SH' - three things on a tray!
cultural_note: The accent (ê) shows it's stressed and the vowel is more closed
tip: Sound like 'traysh' - rhymes with 'mesh' at end

mnemonic: CINCO = 'SINK-O' - FIVE dishes in the sink!
cultural_note: On menus you'll see 'c/5' meaning 'with 5' (com cinco)

mnemonic: SEIS rhymes with 'RAYS' + 'SH' - six sun rays!
cultural_note: Europeans often write 6 with a line through it to distinguish from 0
tip: Rhymes with 'rays' plus 'sh' at the end

mnemonic: SETE sounds like 'SET' + 'UH' - set of seven!
cultural_note: Seven is considered lucky in Portugal too!
tip: Almost like English 'set' with 'uh' at end

cultural_note: Octopus is 'polvo' but octagon is 'octógono' - related to oito

mnemonic: NOVE sounds like 'NOVA' - like Nova Scotia's 9 provinces!
cultural_note: Related to 'novembro' (November - was 9th month in Roman calendar)
Decimal (base 10) comes from Latin 'decem' - same root as 'dez'
